instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-00923 No image
threads.message:
Clean board no water damage and no more history, I have image on external screen.

EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN and PP3V3_S0SW_LCD and PANEL_P5V_EN and PANEL_P3V3_EN come on for about 1 second then leave
All tests are done with good LCD connected and new LCD flex.

threads.title: 820-00923 No image
threads.message: Yes  DP_INT_HPD pulses same as the other ones mentioned before.

threads.title: 820-00923 No image
threads.message: Did you test with another LCD assembly?

threads.title: 820-00923 No image
threads.message: Yes, pulses once same as the other ones mentioned before.

threads.title: 820-00923 No image
threads.message:
Seems to be a problem with CPU eDP video output.
It should detect LCD presence and maintain the voltages, once DP_INT_HPD goes high.

threads.title: 820-00923 No image
threads.message: Can check diode mode to ground on EDP_INT_AUX_N and EDP_INT_AUX_P to see if the transceiver inside the CPU is completely dead at least.

threads.title: 820-00923 No image
threads.message: Thanks [USER=1057]@piernov[/USER]  EDP_INT_AUX_N  is OL and  EDP_INT_AUX_P is 0.211 measured in diode mode, I dont have another board to compare, any input will be greatly appreciated.

threads.title: 820-00923 No image
threads.message:
You must get almost same value on both lines; red probe connected to ground.
The CPU eDP output is damaged...

threads.title: 820-00923 No image
threads.message:
Thanks, that is what I figured, yes red probe on gnd.

Thanks again for all the help.
